Maribel has to bear with the poor road conditions just to bring their harvested rice grains to the market. 
	
Maribel sells rice to earn income and support her family’s needs. She is glad that she is able to respond to the “rice needs” of her neighbors. Maribel has been in the rice retailing business for three years.  She believes that this business will become more successful than the other businesses in the area because rice is the most important staple food in the country. She has always encountered shortages in her stocks because of its very high demand.
	
She is asking for a loan of P5,000 to buy more rice and to avoid her previous experiences. She believes that this money will really help her business. She knows that all her dreams will come true if she can earn more income. She also doubles her time and sacrifices a lot in order to reach all her dreams which include sending her children to school and having her house repaired.

Faith in God and the good relationship among her family serve as her inspiration.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Janeth Del Pilar

texts.es:
La señora Janeth del Pilar es socia del BC “El Alto Mayo”, vive en la Región San Martín, Provincia y distrito de Rioja. Se dedica a la venta de artículos de mercería como vinchas, esmaltes, correas, ganchos, pulseras, colets y juguetes. Su negocio está ubicado en su puesto en el mercado Grau de la ciudad.

Con este préstamo de S/.1,000, el cual será cancelado en 06 meses, comprará   aretes, collares, esmaltes, vinchas y todo tipo de juguetes para surtir bien su negocio y contar con lo necesario para satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes.

Janeth del Pilar tiene 35 años de edad, vive con su esposo y tiene dos hijos que son estudiantes y quienes la ayudan en atender el negocio. Su meta es surtir más su negocio para que no le falten ventas.
texts.en:
Janeth del Pilar is a member of the Alto Mayo Communal Bank. She lives in the San Martin Region, in the province and district of Rioja. She sells merchandise such as hair clips, nail polish, belts, bracelets, and toys. Her business is located in a booth at the Grau Market in the city. With this loan of $350, which will be paid back in six months, she will buy earrings, necklaces, nail polish, hair clips, and all sorts of toys to stock up her business and have everything necessary for satisfying her customers' needs. Janeth del Pilar is 35 years old. She lives with her husband and has two children who are in school and who help her run the business. Her goal is to stock up her business so she doesn't lose sales.

Translated from Spanish by Olivia Engkvist, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase earrings, necklaces, nail polish, hair clips, and toys for her inventory

loans.name: Artesanas Unidas Group

texts.es: El g/s ARTESANAS UNIDAS ellos están en su tercer ciclo son de la comunidad de San Juan de Oriente, son personas humildes pero emprendedoras, tiene la primaria aprobada y eso les permites ser bien expresivas y han logrado tener sus talleres en sus casas y así poder ver a sus hijos y dar trabajo a toda la familia. Con el crédito de adim han tenido la oportunidad de mejorar el nivel de vida de su familia, ya que con las ganancias además de invertir en sus negocios también han realizado mejoras en sus hogares. Doña María Elena L. M. es casada, junto a su esposo han logrado hacer crecer el taller, este oficio lo han aprendido de sus padres y al casarse decidieron establecer uno propio, esta señora expresa que con las capacitaciones de Adim ella ha logrado comprender que es microempresaria y como se debe de llevar controles para no perder en el negocio, ella es quien se entiende por entero de fijar los precios y del control de la calidad de sus productos. Espera seguir obteniendo créditos para seguir mejorando ya que su sueño es mejorar su casa y que sus hijos estudien y tengan un mejor nivel de vida.
texts.en:
The ARTESANAS UNIDAS (United Artisans) group is on its third loan cycle. They live in the town of San Juan de Oriente. They are poor but enterprising people who have completed primary education; this enables them to express themselves and they have established workshops in their homes, enabling them to see their children while also providing work for the whole family.

The ADIM loan has enabled them to improve their family's living standards since they invest their earnings in the business and in home improvements.María Elena L. M. is married. She and her husband have expanded their workshop, in which they have been carrying on the trade learned from their parents since they decided, as newly-weds, to go into business.

Training provided by ADIM has enabled her to understand that she is a micro-entrepreneur and taught her how to monitor things so as not to lose money on her business. She personally sets prices and controls product quality. She hopes to continue obtaining loans so as to continue making improvements; her dream is to improve her house and enable her children to study so that they can have a better standard of living.

Translated from Spanish by John Rynne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in producing handcrafts so as to offer more variety to their customers

loans.name: Saran

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarann C., 52, and her husband, Mr. Thul Poeng, 54, live on an Island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.  They were married in 1982 and have three children: two sons and one daughter who was married and weaves silk at home. One of their sons is a chef at a restaurant.
 
Sarann has been a silk weaver since 1992, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell at market in Phnom Penh. Mr. Thul Poeng is a mason and he also assists his wife in spinning thread when he has free time. 

Sarann is requesting a loan of $500 to install one more loom for her daughter to weave silk to get additional income.

loans.use: To acquire a silk loom.

loans.name: Ikrom

texts.en:
Ikrom is a farmer who is not only devoted to his work but also to being the father of a family. He works hard raising his cattle, which he takes out to graze in the early mornings. Without a doubt this is not an easy task, but his love for his family gives the work reason and meaning. Currently Ikrom wants to improve his situation by increasing the number of cattle he owns, which, in the long run, will provide better financial income. If you support him, he will be forever grateful. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International 

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road, the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi, and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, its culture is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture, and Central Asian traditions. However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and its manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still lives in abject poverty. 

IMON's History 

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing cattle in order to expand the business

loans.name: Srei Chaim Ith Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Srei Chaim I. is the village bank president of twelve people who live in Mkak village, in Takeo province. Each loan will be for different purposes.

She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Srei Chaim also is a fruit seller. Her husband, Sap Key, is a Tok Tok taxi driver. Although they try to work hard, they earn less income than needed to support their family. Thus, Srei Chaim decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets to start a breeding business.

Srei Chaim hopes to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions wI. this loan. She is 25 years old and the mother of a child who is too young to work or study.

loans.use: Buy piglets to start a breeding business.

loans.name: Sabino

texts.es: Sabino tiene 38 años de edad, es casado y tiene dos hijos que viven en su casa. Para él, labrar la tierra es un arte, y lo cultiva con mucho cariño, antes de iniciar sus labores agrícolas primero observa el desarrollo de sus plantas, es ahí donde capta algunos males que puedan acechar, entonces trata de prevenir antes de que se expandan las plagas. En su proceso de cultivo primero siembra papa y abona con los fertilizantes, una vez cosechada, en seguida siembra alverjas, para que de ese modo se evite seguir abonando, por ello que la siembra de alverjas le resulta de poca inversión. Y los precios en el mercado generalmente se mantienen, sin afectar el capital de la inversión. De ese modo trata de sacarle todo el beneficio a cada una de las chacras con estos dos productos. Su mayor dificultad es no contar con terrenos propios. Sabino participa de todas las reuniones de pago, es el encargado de poner la picardía, pues sus compañeros celebran sus bromas. Este es su 7mo préstamo y en todo este tiempo ha venido trabajando con responsabilidad en cada una de sus cuotas. El dinero que solicita es para la compra de fertilizantes para su próxima siembra de papas, y con el resto comprará funguicidas para su chacra de alverjas, de ese modo ayudar en el follaje de esta.
texts.en:
Sabino is 38 years old, married and has two children who live at home. For him, working the land is an art and he cultivates it with great care. Before starting his agricultural labours he first observes the development of his plants, where he removes any bad ones that could threaten the rest, thereby trying to prevent the spread of pests in advance. His cultivation process is first to plant potatoes with an application of fertilizer, then he harvests them, and follows this by sowing peas. In this way he is able to avoid having to use fertilizer so the planting of peas results in a small investment. And market prices are generally stable, without affecting his capital investment. In this way, he tries to reap all of the benefits from each one of his farms with these two products. His greatest difficulty is that he does not own the land himself. Sabino participates in all the payment meetings. He is the funny man and his peers enjoy his jokes. This is his 7th loan and throughout all this time he has worked responsibly on every one of his quotas. The money he is requesting is to buy fertilizer for his next crop of potatoes and with the rest he will buy fungicides for his pea farm that will help leaf growth.

Translated from Spanish by Lara Francis, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is a 28-year-old mother of two children aged 3 and 4. She sells cereals like maize, rice and beans that she purchases from Uganda. Generally, wholesalers come in by sailboat to Dunga Beach in Kisumu, where the storekeepers make purchases. She sells her cereals in a small kiosk in the Kibuye market, Kisumu’s largest open-air market. She is asking for 10,000 KSH to increase her stock because she lacks the finances to do so herself.

Judith recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya. As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive-health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

loans.use: Cereal stock

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana is 34 years old and she is a widowed woman.

She has owned a small food vendor store in the Kihesa neighborhood of Iringa for 10 years. She belongs to Mafifi south group loan (Group code 2026).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of  approximately $115. Each day she works at her business for 12 hours.  


Ana is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items to add to her current stock for the improvement of her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items to add to her current stock.

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
La señora Julia, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Violetas II”, vive en Jr. Imperio Nº 475, Distrito de Nuevo Cajamarca, Provincia San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 51 años, 03 hijos, uno que aun dependen de ella y esta estudiando.

Su impulso  y empeño de ver a sus hijos profesionales, le motivaron a emprender su propio negocio de venta de abarrotes, se encuentra ubicada en su misma casa, un local muy bien acondicionado para atender a sus clientes. 

Las ganancias que genera ayuda al ingreso económico de su familia, ya que es una madre soltera, aprendió a seguir adelante. 
En la actualidad, es muy querida por sus clientes fijos que a diario acuden a su bodega a comprar porque ella cuenta con todo los productos  que el ama de casa necesita y es ella misma quien les brinda su atención con el carisma que le caracteriza.

Con el préstamo de S/ 1,500.00, desea invertirlo comprando arroz y azúcar en sacos, fideos en paquetes, leche y conservas de pescado en cajas y en variedad de marcas, huevos en javas y artículos de higiene personal para continuar dando una mejor atención a sus clientes. 

Julita como le dicen de cariño, se siente con mucha fortaleza para continuar trabajando, día a día agradece a la vida, por brindarle una gran oportunidad de salir adelante como mujer, igualmente al Movimiento Manuela Ramos, por iniciarla a convertirse en una mujer empresaria.
texts.en:
Señora Julia belongs to the Communal Bank "Las Violetas II", and lives in Jr. Imperio Nº 475, a district of Nueva Cajamarca, Province San Martín, Departmento de San Martín. She is single, fifty one years old, and has three children, one who still depends on her and is studying. Her motivation and pledge is to see her children become professionals. They motivated her to undertake her own business selling groceries. Her business is located in her own house, a location very well suited to care for her clients. The profits she generates help the economic income of her family. Since she is a single mother, she learned to get by and keep going. Currently, she is very wanted by her regular clients who daily come to her store for purchases because she has all the products the housewife needs, and she herself gives everyone her attention with the charisma that characterizes her. With the loan of S/ 1,500.00, she will invest in buying rice and sugar in bulk bags, noodles in packages, milk and presreved fish in packets and a varietry of brands, eggs in cartons and articles of personal hygiene, so she can continue giving her clients better attention. Julita, as they say with affection, feels a great deal of fortitude in order to continue working, day by day giving thanks for her life. This loan will be a great opportunity to do well by this women, likewise to the Movement Manuela Ramos, by intiating her conversion to a businesswoman.

Translated from Spanish by Lois Parshley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy groceries to augment her products (rice, sugar, noodles, etc)

loans.name: Yurem Group

texts.es:
Foto de Izquierda a derecha: Zulmira Valquiria M. R., María José Gaitán V. y Martha Lorena F. H..

El grupo solidario Yurem está conformado por tres señoras originarias de Masaya, ellas tiene mucho tiempo de conocerse y tienen mucha confianza entre ellas.

Doña Johana es una joven de 24 años, soltera, madre de dos hijos de las edades tres y un año, con su trabajo ella mantiene a sus hijos, se dedica a la compra y venta de ropa de forma ambulante.Ella sueña con comprar un terreno para construir su casita, puesto que actualmente vive con su mamá, hacer que crezca su negocio, y darle una buena educación a sus hijos.
Con los créditos obtenidos ella expresa que ha podido capitalizarse y ha incrementado sus ventas. Es la coordinadora del grupo y anima a su grupo a ser puntual y cumplido con las cuotas.

María José Gaitán se dedica la venta de calzado variado, sandalias de mujer, zapatos de hombres y niños. Vende ambulante en Masaya y en el mercado, compra sus productos en los talleres de calzado donde ella consigue buenos precios cuando compra al por mayor. Con el crédito compró sandalias de mujer de varios estilos que están de moda. en los jóvenes, tiene muchos clientes, sus productos los vende al crédito y al contado, sueña con mejorar su casa dándole seguridad, tiene un hijo pequeño de dos años.

Doña Martha Lorena F. H. se dedica también a la venta de ropa y zapatos, combinando dos tipos de productos, ella inició vendiendo ropas pero con el tiempo los clientes también le solicitaron zapatos y sandalias. Ella es casada, madre de tres hijos de edades adolescentes y estudian en la escuela mas cercana a su vivienda, ella sueña con darles estudios secundarios y mejorar su casa.

 Este grupo está comprometido a pagar puntual y así seguir obteniendo créditos con Adim, están seguras que con el crédito saldrán adelante porque incrementan sus ventas y así sus ingresos.

Este grupo abona los días Lunes porque, se considera que es el mejor día para abonar, esto porque las ventas del fin de semana son las mejores.
texts.en:
In the photo from left to right: Zulmira Valquiria M. R., María José Gaitán V. y Martha Lorena F. H.. The Yurem Solidarity Group is made up of three women from Masaya. They have known each other for a long time and trust each other very much. Johana is a 24-year-old young woman who is single and the mother of two children who are three and one. She provides for her children through her work. She works at buying and selling clothes as a vendor. She dreams of buying land to build her own house, since she currently lives with her mother, and would like to grow her business and provide her children with a good education. With the loans obtained, she states that she has been able to capitalize and increase sales. She is the coordinator of the group and encourages the group to be punctual and to comply with payments. María José Gaitán works at selling various kinds of footwear, including women's sandals, men's and children's shoes. She sells as a vendor in Masaya and in the market. She buys her products in the shoemaker shops where she gets good prices when she buys them wholesale. With the loan, she bought women's sandals of various styles that are in fashion with the youth. She has many clients, and she sells her products by credit and cash. She dreams of improving her house to give her more security. She has a young son who is two. Martha Lorena F. H. also works at selling clothes and shoes, combining two types of products. She began selling clothes but over time her clients also requested shoes and sandals. She is married and a mother of three teenage children who study at a school near their home. She dreams of them finishing their secondary school studies and of improving her home. This group is committed to paying on time and thus continue to obtain loans with Adim. They are sure that with the loan they will be get ahead because they are increasing sales and therefore increasing their income. This group pays on Mondays because it is considered that it is the best day to pay because weekend sales are the best.

Translated from Spanish by Tara Binetti, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell by credit and cash

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina F. is from the village of Conat, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 35 years old. Lina is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Lina works in a family member's business venture in the arts sector, operating a weaving business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling mats to build nipa huts. Lina has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Lina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. Lina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Lina from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About GDMPC

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products

loans.name: Inobat

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan
       Инобат женщина, которая кредитуется более одного года. Каждый свой кредит она использует целенаправленно на расширение бизнеса. Её ассортимент товара составляет детская одежда и обувь. Следующий кредит на хочет использовать на завоз школьного ассортимента детской одежды и обуви. Она привозит товар из оптового рынка города Истаравшан. Инобат ездит за товаром 2-3 раза в месяц. Инобат через 2-3 дня собирается опять в Истаравшан за школьным товаром.
texts.en:
Inobat is a woman, who has been a borrower for over one year. She uses each of her loans purposefully for business expansion. Her merchandise selection consists of children's clothing and shoes. Inobat wants to use her next loan to bring in school selection of children's clothing and shoes. She delivers her merchandise from a wholesale market in the city of Istaravshan. Inobat goes there 2-3 times per month. Inobat plans to go to Istaravshan in 2-3 days to purchase school merchandise.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of school merchandise

loans.name: Basirat

texts.en: Basirat is 32 years old and married with three children. She sells engine oil. Basirat has been in this business for the past 10 years. She is requesting the loan amount of N40,000 to purchase more engine oil to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more engine oil to sell

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en:
Twenty-eight year-old Chanthy N. was married in 2001 and has three children: two sons and one daughter. She lives on an island in the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Chanthy has been a silk weaver since she was 17 years old. Her husband has been a full time driver since 2008. She is requesting her first loan of US$100 to purchase silk materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Molly

texts.en:
Molly N. is currently in the business of selling beer at the bar and is requesting a loan to improve on the stock.  Molly is 25 years old and is Married with a husband that is a peasant . She has 2 children and her children do not go to school. 

 With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to esterblish distilation of local alcohol for sale.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: improve on the stock

loans.name: John's Group

texts.en:
L. John is a 41-year-old hardworking man who is married with nine children aged 18 years to 4 months. He also takes care of other orphans.

John has been a mechanic in Nantabulirwa for 11 years and he is able to make 100,000/= in weekly profits. He makes metal doors, windows and gates and his biggest business challenge is having to use expensive metals to ensure that he makes quality products to win more customers in order to be able to educate his children.

John needs to secure a loan to be able to boost his business by buying more metal to be used in his business for increased profitability.

loans.use: To buy more metal for his business

loans.name: Karama

texts.en:
Karama P. is currently in the business of selling bread and groundnut phaste. She is requesting a loan to purchase cooking oil, tomatoes and onions to sell.  Karama is 25 years old and is married with a husband who is a farmer. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a motor bike for transporting her supplies.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase cooking oil, tomatoes and onions to sell

loans.name: Estelito

texts.en:
Estelito, 44 years old, has been raising hogs for almost five years now. His net income per week is Php 1,000. He has decided to ask for a loan from generous KIVA lenders amounting to Php 8,000 to purchase hog feed and young piglets to raise.

Estelito's wife is an Overseas Filipino Worker. They have two children: Aljon, 17, and Conrado, 15. They reside in the rural village of Calaocan, Cabatuan, Isabela. Estelito wants to help his wife support the education of their two boys, who are currently enrolled in high school and college level.

loans.use: To purchase hog feed and piglets.

loans.name: Michael Kazungu

texts.en:
Michael Kazungu M. is a 34-year old farmer who lives in Malindi and is married to Janet Kangombe. They have five children between the ages of 11 years and 9 months.

Michael has been in the farming business for the last five years. He was introduced to KADET by an agricultural officer in Malindi. With this loan, Michael plans to pay for farm labor and to buy petrol, farm seedlings, and pesticides. He intends to open his own farm store to sell supplies directly to farmers. (Currently, the farmers buy supplies from brokers.)

He also dreams of building his own hardware shop and describes himself as quiet, focused, and hardworking.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To hire labor and to buy petrol, seedlings, and pesticides.

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Srey S. is a married man and the young father of a lovely kid who is still minor and not enrolled in school.

Srey S. owns and operates a small workshop providing a vehicle repair service. Another source of family income comes from his wife’s business selling a few groceries from home.

Srey S. has been building his new house for a long time but the construction has been suspended due to the lack of money. In order to help finish building his house he has decided to request a loan from Kiva’s partner HKL.

loans.use: To help finish building his house

loans.name: Kitagwenda Rwenzori Sacco Group, Ibanda

texts.en: Vincent M. is the leader of his group in Ibanda. He is 30 years old and married with three children aged 6, 3 and 1. Vincent has had a retail shop in Kitagwenda trading centre for 11 years and he is grateful for his loans because they have helped him increase the stock in his shop as well as to pay fees for his children.  He hopes to educate his children to the highest level of education. This is Vincent’s first loan with the group and he hopes to buy more sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil, and other items all in bulk so that he might be able to make more profit to pay for his children’s education.

loans.use: To buy sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil and other items for a general store.

loans.name: Raquel

texts.es:
Raquel es socia del Banco Comunal Alegría Huamanga.
Raquel es casada, tiene 26 años y 1 hijo, Raquel vende frutas variadas en la puerta de su casa, actividad que realiza todos los días, Además Raquel hace bordados de carteras, correas que vende en el mercado artesanal.
Raquel necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de hilos y materiales para el bordado.
Los sueños de Raquel son tener una empresa y vender sus productos fuera de la región, y tener un minimarket.
texts.en:
Raquel is a member of the Alegría Huamanga Community Bank. She is married, 26 years old and has one son. Raquel sells various fruits in front of her home every day. Furthermore, she also embroiders handbags and belts that she sells at the artisan market. Raquel is requesting a loan of 1000 soles (approximately $350), which she plans to use to purchase thread and other embroidery materials. Her dreams are to have a business and sell her products outside of her region, and to have a minimarket.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase thread and embroidery materials

loans.name: Vong

texts.en:
Vong N. is a 41-year-old and sells vegetables at the local market in Takeo province. She has been operating this business since 2005 and is able to make about $6.60 of profit a day. Her husband has a business transporting fish from the fishermen to resell and distribute to small fish-sellers at the market. On average, he earns $3.30 a day. This couple has three children, two of whom are in school and one is a garment factory worker. 

Vong N. has an idea to invest in a new business in order to increase her daily income. She would like to sell fish as an extra business. In doing this, she expects to have more profit to help raise her standard of living.

loans.use: To invest in a fish-selling business.

loans.name: Milkah

texts.en:
Milkah is 29 years old and married to Daniel Karimi. They are parents to one child, who is in nursery school. Her husband is involved in mobile-phone repairs. They stay in Kikuyu, where Milkah has also put up her retail shop business. This rural/urban kind of a town is very industrious and ideal for business. She has been in this kind of business for the last two years. Her customers are mainly small-scale retailers.

Milkah has not borrowed from other sources and this is her first loan with KADET, a Kiva partner. Together with some of her friends, she formed a group and joined. Milkah plans to add plasticware to her shop, as well as add more stock to the shop of other items like tea leaves, sweets, food spices and many more.

She hopes to grow her business to a wholesale trade so that she can be supplying to others within the town.

loans.use: Milkah plans to buy plasticware items and put them up outside her shop, and also add more stock to her shop

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a 41 year widow.  All of her children died.  She rents a one roomed house with four people in a slum.  There is no electricity or water in the home, but she cares for two orphans and is self reliant. 

She buys raw materials to make a drink and sells it at the Owino Market, one of the big markets in Kampala city.  Grace works seven days a week. 

Grace gets an average of nine customers per day and sells on retail basis. She has been running this business for six years and has been with MCDT and the same group mates for six years. 

This will be her thirteenth loan.  Grace’s major challenge is the rainy season when her customers sometimes stop coming to her for her drink because her place is covered with mud and water.  Thieves sometimes break into her business and steal her drink. Grace wants to buy land so she can construct a commercial house and earn money from tenants.

loans.use: Buy more raw materials like sorghum and millet for making her brew.

loans.name: Irene's Group

texts.en:
Irene V. is from the village of San Juan. She is 23 years old. Irene is the group leader of a five member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Irene Vergaras's Group.

Irene is married and has one infant child. To make a living, Irene owns a general store which sells a variety of different products in the local community. Irene has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Irene joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Irene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Irene is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Argentina Del Carmen

texts.es:
Perfil del Cliente 	Este cliente es una maestra que tiene 17 años de impartir clases y está ubicada en el colegio Miguel Ángel Ortez 
Habita en la comunidad Rigoberto Morales ,atravez de los créditos ha venido construyendo y mejorando su casa
También ha ayudado a preparar académicamente a sus familiares.
También les ha dado preparación académica a sus hijos
Y crearles mejores condiciones donde vive
texts.en:
This client has been a teacher for 17 years at the Miguel Ángel Ortez school. She lives in the Rigoberto Morales community. The loans have made it possible for her to improve the conditions of her home as well as helped her to meet educational expenses of her relatives and her children. They have also created better living conditions where she lives.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To paint her house and buy furniture.

loans.name: Marvin

texts.en:
Marvin R. is from the village of Olango. He is 31 years old. Marvin is married and has 1 school child. To make a living, Marvin owns & operates a agriculture business venture in  planting and harvesting rice for sale. Marvin has been engaged in his business for over 9 years and earns approximately 45000 PHP per harvest.

In 2008, Marvin joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Marvin has successfully repaid a previous loan of 28,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Marvin is requesting a new loan of 31000 PHP which will again be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Marvin from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Porferia

texts.en:
Porferia, 58, is married to Alfredo. They have seven children; the oldest is thirty-five.  She works hard to supplement her family's needs.  She spends most of her day keeping their farm free of pests and weeds. Porferia hopes to improve her next harvest and her earnings.

Porferia is applying for a loan of Php12, 000 from CEVI to buy seeds, fertilizer and other farm inputs.

loans.use: Buy farm supplies.

loans.name: Kovi

texts.en:
Monsieur Kovi A. is 51 years old and is married with three children. He runs a business selling stationery and school supplies, and providing copying services.

Kovi has been in business since 1996. His store is called Ets Koprodis and is located on Boulevard de 30 Août in Adidogomé. His family helps him run his store.

Kovi requests 500,000 CFA to purchase more stationery and school supplies. This is his third loan from WAGES.

loans.use: To purchase more school supplies and stationery for his store

loans.name: Mrs. Chaem Pov Village Bank Group

texts.en: In Manong Leu village in Prey Veng province, ten people are seeking a village bank loan. Mrs. Chaem P. is the group leader, selected by the other members. Each member will use a portion of the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Chaem P. breeds pigs to earn money to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Ken Some, is a farmer who owns a two-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell in order to support his family. Now she has some problems because the soil in her husband’s field is infertile, and it is far away from an irrigation system. To improve production, Mrs. Chaem P. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline. She is the mother of two children, one of whom is a waiter. The other is attending a local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine D. is currently in the business of selling maize flour and rice at the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of beans, rice, etc. to sell.  Catherine is 29 years old and is married to a policeman. She has one child who does not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up her store of goods.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock bags of beans, rice, etc. to sell

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie E. is from the village of Marapong, Sibutad. She is 38 years-old and married with two school-aged children. To make a living, Elsie owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector selling cosmetic items. Elsie has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month. 

In 2010, Elsie joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsie is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used for educational purposes. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Elsie from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For the education of her children.

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en:
Conchita P. is a widow who lives in the village of Bogo in the municipality of Argao in Cebu Province. She earns her living by operating a weaving business. She has eleven children who are 10 to 35 years old. 

Conchita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005, because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past eight loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Conchita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 13,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 9600 PHP, raising her family's standard of living. This time, for her ninth loan, she is borrowing 14,000 PHP, which she intends to use as additional working capital and to buy new equipment for her business in order to continue saving for the future of her family. Conchita P. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than 1 USD a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: For additional working capital

loans.name: Lourdes Roxana

texts.es:
Lourdes tiene 26 años de edad, es soltera y vive junto a su padre y a su madre en el caserío Colera,una zona rural del distrito agrícola de Tambogrande, una zona caracterizada por producir frutas de exportación, pertenece a la provincia de Piura y se encuentra ubicado en la región del mismo nombre, a mas de tres horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica a la crianza y venta de animales menores, ella cría aves de corral al aire libre, cerca a su vivienda, cuando ya han alcanzado un buen nivel de desarrollo las ofrece en venta a sus vecinos y a los negociantes del lugar. Este negocio le permite obtener algunos ingresos con los que ayuda a sus padres con los gastos familiares.

Lourdes desea mejorar la alimentación de sus aves para lograr que se desarrollen de mejor manera y percibir mayores ingresos al momento de venderlas, para lograr su meta ha solicitado por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 500 nuevos con los cuales comprará alimento balanceado.

Lourdes es una joven responsable y trabajadora, su anhelo es seguir apoyando a sus padres y contribuir al mejoramiento de la calidad de vida de su familia. En la zona donde vive sus vecinos y conocidos la consideran una joven tranquila y confiable.
texts.en:
Lourdes is 26 years old, she is single and she lives with her father and her mother in the community of Colera, in the primarily agricultural region of Tambogrande. This region is known for the export of local fruit products, and it is located more than three hours from the city of Chiclayo. She raises and sells turkeys and chickens in a free-range corral close to her home. Once the livestock have reached a certain size she sells them to her neighbors and to businesses in the region. This business grants her a source of income and she is able to help her parents with the family's expenses. Lourdes wants to upgrade the quality of the feed she uses to that they will develop better and get better prices when they are sold. To reach her goal she has approached Edpyme Alternativa (Kiva Field Partner) for the first time, requesting a loan in the amount of 500 soles to purchase high quality feed. Lourdes is a very hard working and responsible young woman. Her dream is to keep helping her parents in continuing to contribute to the improvement of the family's quality of life. In the neighborhood Lourdes is known as a decent and trustworthy young woman.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase high quality feed.

loans.name: The

texts.en:
Mrs. The O. is a villager in Pnov village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Chheng Duong, are farmers. They own two hectares of land where they cultivate rice to sell to support their family. Mr Chheng Duong also owns a mill in the local village.

Her problem is that her rice field is far away from an irrigation system. To improve her production, Mrs. The O. is requesting a loan to buy a pump machine. With the rest of the loan she will buy fertilizer, pesticide, and hire a plow machine to plow her field.

Mrs. The O. was born in 1952. She is a mother of four children. Two attend school, one is a driver, and the other is a farmer. Her husband is shown in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy a pump machine.

loans.name: Maame Esi

texts.en:
Maame Esi D. prepares shea butter (a natural fat extracted from the seed of the African shea tree and widely used in cosmetics as a moisturizer and salve) at Elmina for sale. She is married to a trader and has four children. She has no formal educational background. Maame feeds the family as a way of supporting her husband in taking care of the home.

Esi will use the loan to purchase more ingredients to prepare her shea butter for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, she hopes to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase more ingredients to prepare shea butter for sale

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djekafo, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 41 ans,  3 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Marka-coungo, sous préfecture de Fana,  région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et font la restauration, le commerce de tubercules et de beurre de karité. Ces femmes du groupe Djekafo sont à leur septième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour faire de la restauration, acheter des tubercules et du beurre de karité.                                                                                                                                                                                             
ASSETOU D. du groupe Djekafo compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter des condiments alimentaires et du riz destinés à la restauration.
Elle s’approvisionne généralement avec les grossistes du marché de Bamako et quelques rare fois au marché de Marka-coungo, elle effectue la restauration au marché de Marka-coungo, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 40000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Djekafo group are all 41 years old, married with three children, and live in large traditional families in the village of Marka-Coungo, in the municipality of Fana, in the Koulikoro region (the second largest administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They met through friends and family and sell food, tubers and shea butter for a living. These women are on their seventh microfinance loan which will be used to purchase food, tubers and shea butter. Assetou Diarar, a member of the Djekafo group, aims to use her loan to purchase condiments and rice for the group's restaurant business. She generally sources her goods from wholesalers in the Bamako market and on occasions from the Marka-Coungo market; she then sells food from the Marka-Coungo market for cash or credit sales to a customer base made up of men and women. She aims to generate an average monthly profit of 40,000 FCFA, some of which will be used to see to her family's needs, and the rest will be reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing condiments and rice

loans.name: Silvia

texts.es: Silvia, de 30 años, es una mujer muy sencilla y trabajadora, vive en su casa propia junto a su esposo Alberto de 32 años y sus queridos hijos Roger de 6 y Kevin de 1 año, quienes son el motivo principal de todos sus esfuerzos. El trabajo que realiza Silvia es el cultivo de arvejas, maíz y papas, esta labor la realiza junto a su esposo, quien también trabaja arduamente para obtener ingresos para su familia. Ella ha visto por conveniente llevar sus productos hasta el mercado mayorista de la ciudad de Tarma, ya que según manifiesta, es ahí donde mejores ganancias obtiene. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es cuidar sus cultivos de las plaga de insectos que pueden amenazar su productividad, lleva 8 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es transportar sus productos, ya que el camino es muy largo y agotador. Con el tiempo, espera comprar nuevas tierras para incrementar sus cultivos y con su venta pueda mejorar sus ingresos económicos. Este es el segundo crédito con MFP, se siente en la obligación de pagar todas sus cuotas puntualmente, ya que no quiere causarle problemas a las socias de su banco comunal, en donde es muy querida. Con los mil setecientos nuevos soles que solicita, comprará más abono para mejorar la productividad de sus cultivos.
texts.en:
Silvia, thirty-three, is a very unassuming and hardworking woman.  She lives in her own house with her husband, Alberto, thirty-two; and their two beloved children, Roger, six, and Kevin, 1, the primary reason for all of their efforts.  Silvia grows peas, corn, and potatoes.  She works with her husband, who also works arduously to bring in income for the family.  Silvia finds it convenient to bring her products to the wholesale market in the city of Tarma, since, as she says, it's there that best profits can be made.

What Silvia likes best about her work is protecting the crops from insect infestations that can threaten productivity.  She's been in business for eight years and thinks that the hardest part is transporting the products because the trip is long and exhausting.  In time she hopes to purchase some new land to grow more crops, and increase her income with the sales.  This will be her second loan with MFP, and she feels an obligation to make all of her payments on time; she doesn't want to cause any trouble for the members of her village bank, where she is very well-loved.  With the seven-hundred soles she is seeking, Silvia will buy more fertilizer to improve productivity.

loans.use: To buy sacks of fertlizer.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is a married woman with five children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food for the family.

Irene has rental houses, which she constructed six years ago. Her potential customers are neighbours and town dwellers. She faces a major challenge of delayed payment from tenants. She hopes to build more rental houses in the future.

With her Kshs 40,000 loan, she wants to purchase iron sheets and timber to renovate her rental houses. She decided to join Yehu to get a loan to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase iron sheets and timber to renovate her rental houses.

loans.name: Sokota Ene Sentero

texts.en:
Sokota has been rearing animals for sale in Naivasha town for the last two years.  She is 54 years old and married to Sentero P.. She was introduced to KADET LTD by her friend and this will be her first loan.  She plans to use the cash to buy 12 goats which she will rear and sell later at a profit.

In future, Sokota hopes to grow her business and become a large-scale livestock trader in Naivasha Town.

loans.use: To buy 12 goats which she will rear and sell later at a profit

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina M. is from the city of Capatan, Tuguegarao City. She is a 60 year old single woman. To make a living, Cristina raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Cristina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP when she sells one of her raised animals.

In 2005, Cristina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cristina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. Cristina is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be Cristina's 10th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Altanzul

texts.en:
Altanzul B. lives with her husband and youngest daughter in the Selenge province of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her oldest daughter currently studies at a university in Japan through a scholarship program, and her youngest daughter attends a local primary school, while her middle son lives with his grandparents and will start attending university in 2011. Her husband is a construction worker, but is currently unemployed. 

Altanzul operates a consumer goods trading business out of a rented stall at the local market in her town. In 2007, she moved to her current town and started her business after operating a repair shop in a rented space in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, between 2000 and 2007. Over the years, she has gained significant business experience and has built a positive reputation amongst her customers and suppliers. Her product procurement usually depends on the season, therefore she provides a variety of products that can satisfy her customers. After years of successful operation, she was able to build a house in her yard. For the future, Altanzul hopes to continue being successful with her business and enlarge her house. She has used her business earnings to pay for her daughter's school costs, which has caused her working capital to decrease. She is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan in order to increase her goods and also working capital for her business.

loans.use: To increase her goods and working capital

loans.name: Primitiva

texts.es: Primitiva, de 34 años, convive con Sergio, de 33 años. Ambos tienen 2 hijos: Mirla de 11 y Nelsi, de 9 años de edad. En unión familiar ellos viven en su casa propia, ubicada en la localidad de Ricrican. El principal trabajo de Primitiva, es la compra y venta de animales menores como: cerdos, gallinas, corderos, y cuyes, los que alimenta y engorda para luego revenderlos en el mercado central de la ciudad de Tarma. Pero hace un año, compró un auto con el que realiza trasporte público; cubriendo las rutas Palcamayo y Tarma; en esté negocio, Primitiva obtuvo, muy buenos resultados, pues según menciona; existe poco acceso a los poblados lejanos de la localidad, donde la mayoría de sus habitantes necesita trasladarse a la ciudad para comprar víveres, comestibles y negociar sus cultivos y demás trabajos independientes que realizan. Por ello, está pensando adquirir un auto más, con el que pueda obtener mejores ganancias, y cubrir la demanda de falta de movilidad. Este es el segundo crédito con MFP, y como socia nueva de su banco comunal, se siente alegre de poder compartir su éxito con los demás integrantes. Con el monto que solicita completará el dinero que ahorro para la compra de un auto nuevo, con el cual piensa abastecer la demanda del trasporte público en los anexos lejanos de la ciudad de Tarma.
texts.en: Primitiva, 34 years old, lives with Sergio, 33 years old. They have 2 children: Mirla, 11 years old, and Nelsi, 9 years old. They live together as a family in their own house, located in Ricrican. Primitiva's main job is buying and selling small animals, like pigs, hens, lambs, and guinea pigs, which she feeds and fattens up to later resell in the central market in the city of Tarma. However, a year ago, she bought an automobile for providing public transportation, covering the Palcamayo and Tarma routes. With this business, Primitiva says she has had very good results. There is little access to the villages that are far from town, where most of the residents have to get to the city to buy supplies and groceries, trade their crops and do other standalone jobs. Therefore, she is thinking of acquiring another automobile, with which she could make greater profits and meet the demand due to lack of mobility. This is her second loan with MFP, and as a new member of her communal bank, she is happy to be able to share her success with the other members. The amount she is requesting, together with the money she has saved, will be enough to buy a new automobile, which she plans to use to meet the demand for public transportation in the surrounding areas far from the city of Tarma.

loans.use: It will complete the amount needed to buy an automobile to be used for public transportation.

loans.name: Balinaki Development Group-Jinja

texts.en: Betty N. is 32 years old, married, and has five children. She has run her pub in Likolo, Jinja for one year. She began with savings from her teaching job and food sales business. A variety of alcoholic beverages are offered for sale at her pub. Most of her clients are low and middle income earners around Likolo. Given the low remuneration that she receives as a teacher, this business with its 50,000 UGX weekly profits provides additional income to Betty to help her improve her circumstances and those of her family as well.. With proceeds from this loan, Betty says she is going to revamp her business with purchases of more crates of alcoholic beverages to sell at her pub. Betty belongs to Balinaki Development Group-Jinja.

loans.use: To purchase of more crates of alcoholic beverages

loans.name: Constancia

texts.en:
Constancia is a widow living in Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store. She has six children between 40 and 50 years old. Constancia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1997 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 19 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Constancia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 5,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 3,500 PHP, raising her family's standard of living. This time, for her 20th loan, she is borrowing 15,000 PHP to purchase more stock to sell so that she can continue to save for her future business and family needs. Constancia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Juma

texts.en:
Juma is young and lives with his parents. He owns a retail business and sells clothes and shoes at the market. Juma has been in this business for 6 years already. He is an experienced salesperson and has a stable position at the market. He works by himself and knows how to organize this business well. His business goal is to grow bigger. Juma would like to receive a loan of $2500 USD to increase the assortment of his goods. Having more profit would help him to take better care of his parents and build his own family.  

                                                                  
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new goods for sale

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa is a married woman who lives in Ilog, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a general store, gasoline and buying and selling rice. Her husband Osorio, who is 69 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities. They have seven children who are between 35 and 48 years old. Rosa joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 19 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rosa has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 1,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time for her 20th loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000 to use as funds for her business operation so that she can continue to save up for the future, maintain good health and a successful business. Rosa is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund her business operations

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is a 24 year old single man from Bint Jbeil who has been working as an auto repairer for ten years. He opened his own garage in 2006. Five years ago Mohamad decided to take his own responsibility and start his own business. He thought that he couldn't stay as an employee his whole life, so he took the first hard step and struggled to prove himself, even though he had financial problems at the beginning. This is his first time requesting a loan from Al Majmoua, and it's because he wants to buy an electrical car lifting machine necessary to improve his business. Mohamad hopes to improve his business more in the future and open a car maintenance company.

loans.use: To buy an electrical car lifting machine that is important for his business

loans.name: Sudaba

texts.en:
Sudaba A. is married and raising a son. She and her husband sell women's clothing and shoes in a rented shop in the central market. Sudaba has been in this business for 6 years and it is constantly growing. She usually brings new clothes to the Baku central market once a month.

Sudaba realizes that lending services are very helpful to her business, as loans allow her to increase her turnover capital and expand her business. She would like to make it easier for women to find comfortable and good quality clothing, which is why she is requesting a loan of 1,000 AZN. Sudaba further plans to continue expanding her sales and eventually generate enough profit to improve her family's living standards.

loans.use: to purchase new seasonal clothes

loans.name: Roberto Carlos

texts.es:
El señor D. V. ROBERTO CARLOS es un cliente de  con 35 años, es profesional en el área del Derecho, vive en una vivienda alquilada,  tiene su vivienda en calidad de inquilino en la zona sudoeste de la ciudad en la  provincia Cercado del departamento de Cochabamba.

El señor D. V. ROBERTO CARLOS, presta sus servicios en un bufete de abogados, donde atienden principalmente a personas de escasos recursos económicos y principalmente personas del área rural del departamento de Cochabamba.  

La vivienda en que habita el señor Roberto Carlos es modesta,  cuenta con los servicios básicos completos. 
El señor Roberto Carlos solicita el crédito destinado para la realización de sus trámites en la obtención de titulo en provisión nacional en la rama de abogacía, y de esta manera poder trabajar y apoyar directamente a personas con escasos recursos económicos, así también mejorar sus condiciones de vida con una profesión estable.
texts.en:
Mr. Roberto Carlos D. V. is 35 years old.  He is a Lawyer.  He lives in a rented house in the southwest part of the city in Cercado Province, Cochabamba Department.  His house is modest but has all basic utilities.

He works in a law office whose clients are primarily low-income people from the rural parts of Cochabamba. Roberto Carlos is asking for a loan to pay for the paperwork involved in recognizing his law degree in ‘provisión nacional’ (people who get their degrees from private universities) so that he can work and directly help low-income people as well as improve his living conditions through the exercise of a stable profession.

loans.use: to pay for the paperwork involved with his Law degree.

loans.name: Kihani Turiise Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
K. Medius is the leader of Kihani Turiise group in Ibanda. She is 50 years old, married, and has four children. 

She has a business of selling produce from Kihani with the help of her husband. She has been in the business for over 20 years. She also has a farm from which she sells matooke (green plantain) and coffee. She is able to make 100,000 UGX as weekly profits and she is also involved in the sale of milk and goats. She is very hard working and cooperative and her dream is to be able to educate all her children and have an expanded project. She needs a loan to be able to purchase more produce for resale.

loans.use: to purchase more produce for resale

loans.name: Las Rosas De Maria Group

texts.es:
ALCANCIA COMUNAL LAS ROSAS D. MARIA

La señora Armandina se caracteriza por ser muy alegre y ocurrente, ella es presidenta D. la alcancia comunal LAS ROSAS D. MARIA, elegida por ser carismaticay tratable, ella tiene su bodeguita en su casa y tambien venD. hielo, el cual reparte a pedido D. sus clientes por su zona, ella usara el prestamo para la compra D. mercaderia para su bodega y asi satisfacer mejor los pedidos D. sus clientes, ella sueña con hacer crecer su negocio D. la bodega.
La alcancia comunal LAS ROSAS D. MARIA tiene trabajando con EDAPROSPO-PROSPERIDAD por un año, se caracteriza por ser un grupo alegre y unido, pues todas son vecinas que intentan sacar a sus familias adelante con su trabajo.
texts.en:
Las Rosas D. Maria Community Bank.

Armandina is noted for being very cheerful and witty.  She is the president of the Las Rosas D. Maria community bank and was chosen because she is very charismatic and easy to get on with.  Armandina has a small grocery store in her home and she also sells ice which she delivers to order to customers in her area.  She will use her loan to buy merchandise for her store, so that she can better satisfy her customers' requests.  Armandina dreams of growing her grocery store business.

The Las Rosas D. Maria community bank has been working with Edaprospo-Prosperidad for one year.  They are noted for being a cheerful and united group as they are all neighbors who are trying to get their families ahead in life through their work.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for her grocery store

loans.name: Ruth Del Socorro

texts.es:
Ruth tiene su pequeño negocio una mini pulpería, así como la venta de leña y frijoles cocidos, pues lleva siete años apoyando  a su familia, su esposo trabaja la tierra, trabajando en la agricultura.
Inicio con pocos productos, lo que ha mantenido rotando que es los granos básicos que más se venden, lo que busca alternativa para la inversión y es mediante el préstamo que comienza a invertir a si como pequeñas mejora  a su vivienda.
Con el préstamo anterior logro reparar la mitad del techo poniendo zinc nuevo y la otra parte la invirtió en productos.
Hoy con este nuevo préstamo será destinado únicamente en la terminación completa del techo, comprando láminas de zinc, cuartones, clavos, y hacer la mejora.
texts.en:
Ruth has run a small grocery store selling wood and cooked beans for seven years to support her family. Her husband works on the land in agriculture.

Ruth began her store with just a few products and a constant turn over of staple grains and pulses, the items that she sells the most. Now she is looking for another way to supplement her income through this loan so she can make some small home improvements.

With her previous loan Ruth was able to repair half of her roof by applying a new layer of zinc and spending the other half of the loan on products for her store. She will use this new loan to completely finish her roof by purchasing sheets of zinc, timber and nails to carry out the renovation.

loans.use: to completely replace her roof by purchasing sheets of zinc, timber and nails to carry out the renovation

loans.name: Ruth Elizabeth

texts.es:
En San Ignacio de la  parroquia Colon de la ciudad de Portoviejo cada quince días se reúnen los socios del Banco Comunal San Ignacio De Colon. Lugar conocido por su gente trabajadora y dedicada a la agricultura y la ganadería.
 
En este lugar conocimos a la señora Ruth, tiene 54 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen siete hijos mayores de edad, el menor de ellos es el que  aun vive con ella y estudia medicina en la universidad. Su esposo es chofer. Lleva en el banco comunal cinco ciclos y le gustan los créditos, las charlas y sus compañeras que son muy unidas.

Ella tiene una tienda de comestibles en su casa en la cual vende todo tipo de productos, tanto de primera necesidad como también artículos de bazar, papelería, bebidas y  helados. Trabaja todos los días desde las 6h00 hasta las 21h00 y a veces hasta más tarde, su hijo y su esposo le ayudan en su trabajo cuando tiene tiempo, pero por lo general ella siempre está en ella ya que allí se entretiene. Tiene más de seis  años su negocio y nos cuenta que empezó con poco y con cada crédito ha ido aumentando poco a poco.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su tienda, va a comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, detergentes, embutidos y productos de papelería y bazar.

Sus metas son seguir adelante con su tienda y crezca cada día más.
texts.en:
The members of the San Ignacio de Colon communal bank meet fortnightly in San Ignacio, parish of Colon, city of Portoviejo. The place is known for its hard-working people who work in agriculture and livestock.
 
Here we met Ruth, 54, married with seven grown-up children. The youngest of them still lives with her and he's studying medicine at the university. Her husband is a driver. She has completed five cycles with the community bank and enjoys the loans, the chats and the company of the other members, who are all very close. 

She owns a grocery store, located in her home, where she sells all kinds of products - staples as well as miscellaneous items, stationery, drinks and ice-cream. She works from 6am to 9pm every day, sometimes even later. Her son and husband help her with her work when they have a bit of time, but she's usually always there as it also keeps her busy. She has run the business for over six years and she explains that it started with very little, and that with each subsequent loan it has slowly expanded.

She will use the loan to stock up her store. She's going to buy rice, sugar, oil, detergent, cold meats and stationery and other products.

Her goals are to continue to run her store and get it to grow every day.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, detergent, cold meats and stationery and miscellaneous products.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius Wanyama is  28 years and runs a motorcycle spare parts shop in Kitale town. 

He has been in this business for five years and he is applying for a loan of KES.60,000, with which he intends to expand the business by adding more stock.
 
His dream is to have a big spare part outlet and improve the living standards of the family

loans.use: to purchase more stock for the business

loans.name: Mena Ama

texts.en:
Mena is married and has five children. Her husband is a farmer.

She sells pepper, salted fish, onions and other things at Elmina. Mena has been in this trade for seven years. She responsibly assists her husband in the payment of household expenses and school fees. 

Her loan will be used to buy more of the food items mentioned above to sell. She wishes to build a shop with the new profit.

loans.use: to buy food to resell.

loans.name: Bessik

texts.en:
Bessik is a 36-year-old farmer from the village of Meskheti in West Georgia. He lives with his wife, Tinatin, a 4-year-old daughter, his mother and his retired aunt. 

Bessik has 15 years experience in farming. Bessik’s family has a plot of the land where he grows cucumbers, greens and watermelons. He sells the harvested products on the local market. All the adult family members take part in seasonal work on the plot. 

Bessik also trades scrap iron. The total average income of the family is 1,000 GEL per month. 

Along with the plot of land, Bessik has a steel structure of a greenhouse. He needs to purchase glass and cellophane to cover the structure and make the greenhouse ready for the fall and winter seasons. He plans to sow greens in the greenhouse, which will be sold to wholesalers. 

Using the greenhouse productively will significantly increase the income of the family. Part of the increase in income will be reinvested in the farm and the other part will be used for house renovation.

loans.use: to purchase glass and cellophane for the greenhouse.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en: Marilyn is 45 years old, married and has five children. She works as a farmer who tills a plot of land in the town of Banga, South Cotabato. She and her husband work together on their farm, where they grow rice to sell to their customers.
