Mahfuza is married with two children. This is an average family from Dushanbe, Tajikistan. However, Mahfuza is a unique entrepreneur. She has been selling kids' clothing in the central city market for about 2 years, running her own small venture successfully. The secret of her success is simple: she tries to not only let her customers know the benefits of her products – she also gives them a sense of relationship which brings them back again and again. However, she doesn’t want to stop where she is at with her venture.

Mahfuza is seeking a loan of 3400 Somoni to re-stock the merchandise in her store for the winter season. We believe that Mahfuza’s desire to excel in pleasing her customers will determine her further success and encourage new customers to buy from her.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing  winter clothing for kids

loans.name: Or

texts.en: Or V., 21, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province, Cambodia. She works with her husband making incense from their home, to earn a living. They are able to make about $5 of profit per day. She would like to use this loan to purchase a motorbike and increase the number of incense sticks that they sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Mukangango

texts.en: Greetings from Kigali, Rwanda!  E. Mukangango is currently seeking her first loan from Vision Finance Company in Rwanda worth 500,000 Rwandan Francs.  She owns a shop selling secondhand clothes in the Kimironko neighborhood of Kigali.  With the loan, she hopes to expand her business by increasing her stock of secondhand clothing.  At this time, she buys the clothing in bulk and sells it at retail value so that she can earn a profit.  The loan will enable her to buy more stock and increase her sales.  With the increased profits, E. hopes to pay school fees, buy more food for her family, and reinvest in her business.  E. is 28 years old, married, and has 3 children.  She also cares for three orphans.  She began her business in 2005 and currently employs two people to help her run her shop.

loans.use: buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Mat

texts.en:
A small-size stone house and a grocery store in the Phsa Lach Village of Phnom Penh City belongs to Mrs. Mat D.. 

Mat, 26, is a grocery seller.  She sells her wares to neighbors in the village, including cooked ingredients, sweets, plastic goods etc.  She generates a daily income of $4 to help feed her family.  To help with the family's living expense, her husband is a building worker.  The couple has two teenage children who are going to school. 

To increase her stock of groceries, Mat requests a loan to buy more produces to sell.  As another revenue source, she purchases fresh fishes to sell at the marker.

loans.use: Buy more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Irene Maria

texts.es:
La señora Irene Maria G. E. D. U. tiene 49 años, vive en AA.HH. Aurora Díaz, distrito D. Salaverry, provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudió Enfermería Técnica, carrera que abandono debido a que salio embarazada y tuvo que dedicarse a su hogar. Tiene 04 hijos D. los cuales solo 01 depenD. D. ella económicamente. 
Irene tiene una bodega, al inicio se dedicaba a la venta D. abarrotes en el mercado, luego decidió abrir una pequeña bodega en sociedad con su cuñada, con el tiempo a ampliado su negocio con la venta D. productos D. belleza, ropa y juguetería, con las ganancias que ha obtenido a comprado una exhibidor y una vitrina para sus productos. Su negocio lo desarrolla en su propio domicilio.
Con el primer crédito D. 300 soles que recibió D. su banco comunal “Jerid Camino al Éxito II”, lo invirtió en la compra D. productos D. belleza y peluches. 
Con el crédito D. 2000 soles, que será cancelado en  6 meses, lo invertirá en la  compra D. productos D. belleza y ropa.
Irene sueña con tener una librería y una tienda D. ropa.
Ella pertenece al club D. madres D. su sector.
texts.en:
Irene Maria G. E. D. U. is 49 and lives in the Aurora Díaz Settlement in the Slaverry District of the Trujillo Province in the Department of La Libertad, Perú. She had studied Vocational Nursing, a career she gave up when she became pregnant and needed to devote herself to her home. She has 4 children, only one of whom is dependent on her. Irene has a grocery store. At first she maD. her living selling groceries at the market, but then she decided to open a small grocery store with her sister-in-law. Over time she has expanded her business by selling beauty products, clothing, and toys, and she has used her profits to buy a display and a showcase for her products. She's building her business in her own home. Irene invested her first loan of 300 soles, which she received from her village bank, "Jerid Camino al Éxito (Road to Success) II," in beauty products and stuffed animals. She plans to use this loan of 2000 soles, which she will repay in 6 months, to invest in beauty products and clothing. Irene dreams of opening a bookstore and a clothing store. She belongs to her local mothers' club.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy beauty products and clothing

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia N. is 45 years old and she is divorced and a mother of one child who is currently working. She got divorced nine years ago after her husband got someone else pregnant. Meanwhile, she was doing everything to satisfy the husband. She lives in Oda in the Eastern Region of Ghana. She is a trader who deals with assorted products, such as cooking utensils, clothing materials, ladies slippers, etc. She mostly sells through hawking (house to house selling) and has been in this trade for six years. With her humorous behavior, she has attracted lots of customers who purchase from her. 

She treks to Accra to purchase her stock of goods and recently she has been facing challenges in her business as a result of inadequate funds to buy stock. She requests a loan to buy more supplies of the products like cooking utensils, clothing materials and ladies slippers which are frequently demanded by her customers. With the loan she would have more resources to make lots of profits to build a store and reduce the frequent walking on the street to sell. She belongs to a village bank called ‘Ahotefo’ which literally means Saints. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To increase her stock of inventory like cooking utensils, clothing materials, slippers etc.

loans.name: Ratifa

texts.en:
Ratifa, a 44-year-old married mother of five children: ages 16, 14, 13, 10 and 4, also cares for five additional dependents. A member of Ngome north group loan (Group code 2032), Ratifa has owned a small food-vending store in the Kihesa neighborhood of Iringa for five years. Working everyday for 12 hours, she currently earns an average monthly profit of approximately $100.

Ratifa is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania in order to expand her business by purchasing more food items to add to her current stock. She is hoping that through this loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

loans.use: To add more food items to her current stock in order to expand her business.

loans.name: Flora

texts.en: Flora L. is from the town of Lumbia, Cagayan De Oro City. She is 37 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. Flora owns and operates a business selling “ukay-ukay” (slightly-used clothes) in the local market. Flora has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month. In 2009, Flora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the needs of family members. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

location.town: Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Ni Wayan Suarmi

texts.en:
Ni Wayan Suarmi (DNR.M-0572) is a 56-year-old married mother of four adult-aged children living in the town of Brawantangi - Melaya. To making a living, Ni wayan Suarmi aised livestock. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Ni wayan Suarmi has been engaged in this business for over eight years, earning approximately 1,000,000 IDR a month.

In 2007, Ni wayan Suarmi joined DINARI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 3,500,000 IDR from DINARI that was used to purchase baby livestock to raise, she is now requesting a new loan of 5,000,000 IDR which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. The loan will be her fourth from DINARI, and Ni wayan Suarmi plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support extended members of her family.

About DINARI: The mission of DINARI is to strive for the preservation of the environment, to empower the poor, and to provide socio-economic development opportunities to small business owners.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Bahasa while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies.

loans.name: Mercedes Elena

texts.es: La señora Mercedes tiene su pequeño snack en la zona de Pampahasi, donde vende rellenos (especie de empanada) , es un aperitivo hecho de papa, yuca o plátano aplastado hasta que se vuelva masa, con un relleno de carne y cebolla y condimentos. Tiene muchos clientes ya que prepara rellenos sabrosos. Vive en su propia casa, no tiene hijos pero se dedica  mucho a sus sobrinos y a su papá que es de la tercera edad. El crédito será invertido en la compra de viveres para los rellenos y comprará, también, cemento para la construcción de unas piezas en su casa para  alquiler. Es una cliente puntual.
texts.en:
Mercedes has a small snack shop in the zone of Pampahasi where she sells rellenos, a type of empenada made from potato, yuca or plantains, with a filling of meat, onions and condiments. She has a lot of customers who come for her delicious rellenos. She lives in her own house. She doesn't have children, but she dedicates a lot of time to her nieces and nephews, as well as her elderly father. The requested loan will be used to purchase ingredients needed to make her rellenos, as well as to purchase cement to construct another floor in her home so that she can rent out space. Mercedes is a punctual client of the communal bank.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for the snacks she makes and sells, as well as construction materials to add a floor to her home so that she can rent out the additional space.

loans.name: Folashade

texts.en:
Folashade is happily married with 3 children and she is 41 years old. She sells drinks, juice, and pepper soup, and she has been in this business for the past 5 years. Folashade keeps her shop open from 6am to 12am from Monday to Sunday and she is very happy and proud to have LAPO and Kiva as her financial source. She lives in Lagos State.

Folashade is requesting the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more drinks, juice, and pepper soup ingredients to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks, juice and pepper soup ingredients

loans.name: Mrs. Yi Seng Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Nineteen people living in Boeng Satong village in Takeo province comprise this village bank loan, and they will use the loan for various purpose. Mrs. Yi S. is a 23- year-old village bank president. She is a grocer who owns a grocery store. Since her business is doing well, she has a lot of consumers who need many demands. Thus, she decided to request a loan to buy more grocery products to add her business to earn more profits. Her husband, Mr. Eng Chan Veasna, is a farmer who owns 1.5-hectar field of land to cultivate rice. This couple has three children, one of whom is attending the local school while the others are too young to work or study. 

Twelve members in this group loans are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To request a loan to buy more grocery products to add her business to earn more profits.

loans.name: Améyo

texts.fr: Cette dame est mère de 02 enfants. En 1992, elle a été bouleversée dans sa vie privée par le divorce qu’elle a eu avec son mari. Elle a désormais la charge de ses enfants. C’est pour cela qu’elle s’est lancée dans le commerce d’alimentation générale et des produits divers. Actuellement elle a beaucoup de clientèle ; sa boutique se situe dans le Grand Marché de Lomé. Elle a un besoin pressant de renouveler son stock ; pour cela elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 20 cartons d’eau minérale Voltic, 05 boîtes de Nescafé, 03 boîtes de lait Nestlé, 15 boîtes de savons de lessive BF. Elle souhaite également se lancer dans le commerce des articles scolaires ; c’est pourquoi ce prêt lui permettra aussi d’acheter 15 cahiers de 100 pages, 30 cahiers de 200 pages et bien d’autres articles

loans.use: achat de produits d'alimentation générale et d'articles scolaires

loans.name: Celia

texts.en:
Celia is married to Abner, who works as a government employee. She is 45 years old and is blessed with three children. Haydee, her eldest, is currently living in Jordan and working as a factory worker. Hayleen is a fourth-year college student. Absel, the youngest, is also in college. Sending them to college is very costly. Celia hopes that her children will finish their studies with her financial support. 

To help her husband in providing for the growing needs of their children, Celia began selling beauty soaps. She gets orders from people in her community and then purchases her products in Tumauini, Isabela. She also maintains a hog-raising business in their home. To further grow both of her businesses, Celia is requesting a loan for PHP9,000 from Kiva lenders. She hopes to obtain a loan from lenders to have her business raise more capital. She plans to purchase stocks of beauty soaps and feed supply for her hogs to help them grow bigger. She hopes that her loan will be approved so that her businesses will remain stable.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Makau

texts.en: Makau M. is a 53-year-old widow from Nambale, Busia District, in Kenya.  She has eight children. Makau sells both fresh and fried fish as a way of generating income for her big family. She has been involved in this business since 1984 (25 years). Makau says she restocks twice a week. She needs a loan of Ksh 20,000, which she says she will use to buy more fish and expand her business. She wants to secure her children's further education, both currently and in the future.

loans.use: Buy more fish stock and expand business

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia M. is from the village of Malagana, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 45 years old. Lydia is married and has eight school-aged children. To make a living, Lydia provides beauty services such as manicures and pedicures to local community members. Lydia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lydia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lydia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from HSPFI. Lydia is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Lydia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Khen

texts.en:
Khen K. is 45 years old and married.  His wife is a local cultivator, and they have five children.  Two of his children are married and the others attend school. 

Khen K. currently generates an income of approximately $4 per day by selling marble. First, he purchases large marble blocks from people who live near the mountains, then he carves and breaks down the marble blocks into small pieces, and finally he sells the marble pieces to people who need them to carve statues. 

Typically, Khen K.  hires his neighbor’s water buffalo to transport the marble to be sold. To help reduce his costs, Khen K. is applying for a loan to purchase a pair of water buffalo which he will use to pick up and deliver the marble.

loans.use: To purchase a pair of water buffalo to pick up and deliver marble

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohmmad is a young single man; he owns a shop in a very busy location in the old city of Bethlehem.

Mohammad started with vegetable kiosk (since his father also owns a vegetable shop) when he was very young and from the income of this kiosk, a year ago he started a partnership with one of his friends in this shop where he sells cosmetics, perfumes, accessories, scarves.....the shop is managed by both Mohammad and his friend, and Mohammad still has his vegetable kiosk next to this shop.

Mohammad is a very ambitious young man. He hopes that he will be able to have good source of income from these two businesses and ultimately will start his own family.

Mohammad requested 2000 USD from Faten to buy some products for his shop as it is Eid Al-Adha next week and the demand for his products became greater. Mohammad appears in the picture at his business.

loans.use: Buy products for the shop

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein has owned a photography shop since 2007. He has been working in photography for the past 8 years. He's 36 years old. He really loves his job because he think that it's creative and artistic. Today, Hussein is requesting a loan of $1,200 to buy a new photography machine.

loans.use: To buy a new photography machine

loans.name: Hermenegilda

texts.es: Hermenegilda tiene 39 años, vive con su pareja y sus tres hijos en su casa que es  propia.Desde hace 5 años se dedica a la atención de su pequeña tienda de comestibles que esta ubicada en su casa; optó por este trabajo  ya que le daba la libertad de poder dedicarse a sus hijos y a las labores del hogar, además le gusta mucho el trabajo ya que la motiva y se siente muy independiente, además le da esperanzas de un futuro mejor para su familia. Algunas veces sus hijas la ayudan en la atención y así puede ir a comprar  mayor cantidad de mercadería, pero otras  veces se queda en la tienda sin poder salir ya que el negocio esta abierto de lunes a viernes, desde tempranas horas de la mañana hasta las 8 o 9 de la noche. En un futuro espera hacer ampliar  su negocio y quiere ofrecer novedades y productos que hagan que su tienda sea mucho más visitada.Es su cuarto préstamo en MFP, y asegura será muy puntual en todos sus pagos.Con el dinero del crédito comprará mayor cantidad de panetones (bizcochos  navideños) ya que durante  el mes de diciembre  son muy solicitados.
texts.en:
Hermenegilda is 39 years old and lives with her partner and their children in their own house. For 5 years she has been tending her small grocery store located in her house; she chose this work because it gave her the freedom to take care of her children and the housework; additionally, she likes her work very much because it motivates her, it makes her feel independent and it gives her hope of a better future for her family. Sometimes her daughters tend to the store so she can go buy more merchandise, but other times she cannot go out and must stay in the store because the store is open Monday through Friday, from early in the morning until 8 or 9 pm. In the future, she wants to expand her business by offering novelty products that can attract more customers to visit her store. This is her fourth loan with MFP, and she is confident to make her payments on time. With the money from the loan, she will buy a higher quantity of panetones (Christmas biscuits) since they are in high demand during the month of December.

Translated from Spanish by Carlos Morales, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more merchandise

loans.name: Yadira Del Rosario

texts.es:
La señora Yadira Vanegas vive en el municipio El Viejo en Chinandega y se siente muy satisfecha porque ha logrado suplir las necesidades para el desarrollo intelectual de su hija que hoy en día está finalizando sus estudios universitarios.
Doña Yadira ha sido fiel cliente de Ceprodel habiendo realizado créditos anteriormente los que han sido utilizados para el pago de la universidad de su hija. Hoy en día el crédito que solicita lo utilizará directamente para el pago del título universitario de su hija para así sentirse satisfecha que ha apoyado a su amada hija en este largo camino y que ahora espera gozar de los privilegios de tener una hija profesional a la que tanto ama.
texts.en:
Ms. Yadira Vanegas lives in the El Viejo municipality of Chinandega. She feels very satisfied for having been able to provide her daughter, who is now completing her university studies, with an education. Ms. Yadira has been a faithful client of Ceprodel, having had previous loans that were used to pay for her daughter’s schooling. The loan she is requesting today will be directly used to pay for her daughter’s college degree. This way, she will feel very content to have supported her beloved daughter on this long road. She hopes to now enjoy the benefits of having a professional daughter whom she loves very much.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay for her daughter's college degree.

loans.name: Amalita

texts.en: Amalita O. is from the village of Salay, Misamis Oriental. She is 42 years old, is married, and has three adult children. Amalita owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling specialty food products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Amalita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna N. is currently in the business of selling greens and tomatoes in the market and is requesting a loan to purchase more greens and fruits to sell.  Anna is 22 years old and is married to a fisherman. She has two children who do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more greens and fruits to sell

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en: Elsie E. is 29 years of age and her only child is five years old. Being poor and dependent to her husband’s small and sporadic income, Elsie is worried for her child’s future. In her heart and mind all she wants is the best for him and his future by finishing his education so he can find the best career for himself. To achieve this dream for her child she joined ASHI and has requested a loan to grow her small “sari-sari” (variety) store. Elsie is a woman filled with love and inspiration because her family stays together through good and bad times.

loans.use: To purchase variety of good to sell in her store.

loans.name: Lerma's Group

texts.en:
Lerma M. is from the village of Cabaritan. She is 37 years old. Lerma is the group leader of an eight-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Lerma M.'s Group.

Lerma is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Lerma owns & operates a furniture making business. The main source of income for the business comes from making & selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Lerma has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lerma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lerma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase wood for her furniture business. Lerma is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials for her furniture making business, such as wood and varnish. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Lerma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it.

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials for furniture making business

loans.name: Jean De Dieu

texts.en:
Jean de Dieu is 41 years old and is married with three children who are 6, 7 and 11 years old.

Jean de Dieu is known as a self-employed businessman selling bread, cosmetics products, and other types of goods as the photo indicates. He has been in this business for about five years and the hours of his business are from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m. every day.

Although Jean de Dieu has been in this business for about five years, his seed money is still too low to earn sufficient profits. Better profits could be used for further reinvestment in his business, thus improving his family situation and saving for a better future.

To fix this situation, Jean de Dieu is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company which hopefully will help him to achieve a lot via his business.

loans.use: To purchase bread, cosmetics products and another goods to expand his business

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James has been supplying fuel and paraffin in Naivasha town for the last five years. His target market is the low income earners within Naivasha town. He is 22 years old, married to Ruth Nyawira, and they have a nine-month-old baby. He also has a secondary business where he carries people and goods on his motorbike and thus improving on his income base.

James was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his third loan, having repaid the previous two loans well and on time. He plans to add to his stock of fuel and paraffin (kerosene) for selling in his shop.

In future, James plans to diversify and venture into the transport business owning a fleet of Matatus (Minivans) which will operate on the Nairobi - Naivasha route.

loans.use: To add to his stock of fuel and parrafin in his shop

loans.name: Constance

texts.fr: M. Constance est née en 1980 et vit depuis vingt ans environs à Sainte Cécile, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Constance est mariée à DOHOU Honoré, un soudeur, et est mère d’un enfant qui est scolarisé. Constance vit ensemble avec son mari et son enfant. Le couple se partage les différentes charges de la maison. Constance a bien vite abandonné l’école et a appris ensuite la coiffure. Constance exerce cette activité depuis une dizaine d’année. Parallèlement, Constance vend aussi des mèches, des pommades et d’autres produits de cheveux dans son atelier de coiffure, situé dans son quartier. Constance a déjà obtenu deux fois de prêt à ALIDé et les a tous bien remboursés. Constance désire agrandir davantage son atelier par l’achat d’autres produits de cheveux, ce qui lui permettra de mieux répondre à sa clientèle et de se faire plus de profits. C’est pour ce fait que Constance sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un troisième crédit.
texts.en:
Constance M. was born in 1980 and has lived for around 20 years in Sainte Cécile, a district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Constance is married to Honoré DOHOU, a welder, and is mother to one child who attends school. She lives with her husband and child. The couple shares the various household expenses. Constance left school at an early age and learnt the hairdressing trade. She has been carrying out this activity for around ten Years. At the same time, she also sells hair extensions, creams and other hair products in her hairdressing salon, which is situated in her neighborhood. Constance has already had two loans from ALIDé and has repaid them both without problem. She would like to expand her salon by buying more hair products; this will enable her to respond better to customer demand and make more profit. For this reason, Constance is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of hair extensions, creams and beauty accessories

loans.name: Rabbeca

texts.en: Rabbeca is 24, married, and has been in business for two years. She sells household products such as sufurias (cooking pots), spoons, buckets and cups. She has requested for a loan of Kes. 20,000 to add to her inventory. She has begun saving since she joined Faulu Kenya Limited and hopes to own a wholesale shop in the future. She describes herself as hardworking.

loans.use: To add inventory

loans.name: Salama

texts.en:
H. is a happily married woman with six children who all attend school. She owns a house with no electricity but with piped water. She notes that her greatest monthly expenses are school fees.

With this KES 40,000 loan, H. hopes to purchase wheat flour, cowpeas and sugar for her business which she has been operating for the past 24 years. Before that, she was employed as a secretary. She gets assistance for the business from her husband, who works as a driver.

H.'s major challenge is seasonality. She hopes to build houses for rental purposes and improve her family's living standards. She joined Yehu because of its accessibility to sustainable financial services.

loans.use: To buy wheat flour, cowpeas and sugar

loans.name: Khem

texts.en:
Khem K., 33, is a middle-aged man (wife in photo) villager living in Phnom Pen, the capital of Cambodia. Since the beginning of 2008, Khem has owned an old bicycle and used it to provide a taxi service.  His wife owns a shop inside a market where she sells grocery items to earn a living. 

The couple has two school-aged kids.  Khem’s wife has sold nearly all her items and she hopes to restock her inventory.  Khem is requesting a loan for his wife to increase her grocery inventory.

loans.use: Increase grocery inventory.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is a 32 year-old woman who runs a general store in a busy market area selling a variety of goods, including sugar, flour, soda, utensils, and even some clothing.  She has been in this business for 3 years and her primary business challenge is bad debts from creditors that don’t pay. Before running her store, she sold tomatoes.  Nancy has two children, a daughter 6 years old and a son almost 2 years old.

Nancy plans to use the 70,000 Kenya Shilling loan to increase the stock in her store (utensils, sugar, flour, etc.).

In the future, she hopes to expand from retail into wholesale.  In 5 years, she would like to see her children through school and to increase her income by significantly expanding her business.

Nancy describes herself as honest, determined, and hardworking.

loans.use: To increase the stock of the store (utensils, sugar, flour, etc.)

loans.name: Buliisa Kwegata, Mubende Group

texts.en:
Sennyonga J., aged 36, is a peasant farmer who grows food crops such as beans and maize to sell to produce and grocery dealers. He is very hardworking and his ambition is to own a big agricultural farm in his home area of Buliisa, Mubende.
J. has developed a strong attribute of determination that, along with his strong, hardworking attitude, has played into his hands, giving his ten-year enterprise a dependable niche. With monthly profits to the tune of 200,000 UGX, J. believes that the sky is the limit for what he intends to achieve. With this loan, he hopes to purchase fertilizers to improve his farm as well as pesticides as pests have affected crops hence reducing yields. This will improve his yields and sales revenue and enable him to live a more satisfying life.

loans.use: To purchase pesticides and fertilizers

loans.name: Otgonbayar

texts.en:
Otgonbayar is 37 years old and lives with his wife, father-in-law and two children, Shinebayar, 20, and Shinebileg, 18, both of whom are university students. Otgonbayar has been running his spare truck parts retail business for 10 years. He buys brand new new spare parts from wholesalers and sells them on the local market. He also sells secondhand parts, which he collects, fixes and replenishes. His business is doing very well because brand new spare parts for big trucks are very expensive. He has his own customers and his products are in good demand. He has taken out 3 loans from MFI already and has used them appropriately.

Otgonbayar has bought a piece of land and built a house on it. The family is very happy to have its own house now. Otgonbayar's father-in-law is 70 years old and is half-paralyzed, needing constant care. So Otgonbayar's wife takes care of her father. Otgonbayar is requesting this loan because he wants to increase his working capital and inventory. Also, higher education in Mongolia costs a quite a lot of money. Therefore he wants to pay for his two sons' annual university fees. One of his sons, Shinebayar, will graduate next summer.

loans.use: to increase his working capital and to pay his two sons' annual tuition fees

loans.name: Edwin

texts.en:
Edwin M. is from the town of Banga. He is 44 years old and is married with three children.

Edwin owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. He also raises pigs for fattening that he sells to his community.

Edwin joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.

Edwin is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm inputs and feeds for his pigs. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business and financially support his family.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs and feeds for his pigs

loans.name: Santa Rosa De Yanacoto Group

texts.es:
ALCOM: SANTA ROSA D. YANACOTO

Socia D. L. ALCOM: “SANTA ROSA D. YANACOTO” quienes sus integrantes son personas muy emprendedoras y esforzadas cada uno en su propio negocio.

 Cecilia empezó a trabajar desD. muy niña al lado D. su madre quien vendía medicinas naturales en su tierra D. Huánuco, muy joven se casó a L. edad D. 14 años quien emprendió con el negocio D. abarrotes, pocos años después deciD. hacer lo que aprendió a su corta edad L. venta D. medicinas, medicamentos naturales, empleando los conocimientos D. su madre, como el D. curar ciertas enfermedades D. vías respiratorias, dolores musculares, infecciones leves. A su vez también vendió ropas y polos, así fue que deciD.  emigrar a L. ciudad D. Lima, esta vez tuvo que recomendarse con su propio trabajo dado que era un lugar nuevo, en L. que no había competencia en lo que elL. vendía, como nos cuenta implementó mas en mercadería con los créditos que tuvo D. EDAPROSPO-PROSPERIDAD, así pudo adquirir con las ventas un puesto propio en un lugar comercial donD. sus ganancias son buenas, el secreto D. ello se debe a que Cecilia es una persona que aparte D. conocer bien las propiedades curativas D. cada planta, sirve a L. sociedad especialmente a personas ancianas a quienes no les cobra el remedio que elL. prepara. Este trabajo le ayudó mucho a crecer, porque asistió a charlas y conferencias que L. invitaron, tuvo L. oportunidad D. viajar al país D. Ecuador, los exponentes eran médicos terapéuticos lo cual profundizó mas sus conocimientos, es así que también elL. compartió secretos curativos que comprobó durante tratamientos a sus clientes a estos médicos especialistas. No solamente ese trabajo pudo comprar el terreno donD. actualmente vive, además D. construirlo, adquirir artefactos, sino también educación a sus hijos; los clientes buscan su servicio quienes son muchos D. ellos gente profesional (abogados, políticos, enfermeras, doctores) y gente del pueblo, quienes agradecen a Cecilia por haberles curado D. ciertas enfermedades tales son los casos D. cáncer, tumores, quistes, miomas; siempre y cuando no sea necesario una intervención quirúrgica, si es así elL. les dice a sus clientes que deben D. hacerlo porque esto lo vio en las radiografías y ecografías. Agradece a Dios por haberle guiado en este camino, D. ayudar a personas con mucho amor a través D. sus conocimientos. Su anhelo es viajar con los médicos a Estados Unidos para que conozca y difundan esta forma D. curar.

El crédito que requiere es para incrementar jarabes, hierbas, y otros medicamentos curativos naturales.
texts.en:
ALCOM: SANTA ROSA D. YANACOTO Member of ALCOM: "SANTA ROSA OF YANACOTO” whose members are progressive and hardworking with their own businesses.

Cecilia began working since childhood with her mother who sold natural medicine in her homeland Huánuco. She married at the young age of 14 and began a grocery business. A few years later, with all she had learned, she decided to sell medicine, natural meiecine, and started applying her mother's knowledge of curing certain ailments such as respiratory tract diseases, muscle pain, and mild infections. At the same time she sold clothes and polos and it was then that she decided to move to Lima. This time she had to recommend herself since it was a new place. There was no competition for her business so she was able to implement more in merchandise with the loans she received from EDAPROSPO-PROSPERIDAD. With the sales she was then able to have her own stand in a shopping center where her sales are very profitable. The secret is that besides Cecilia being a specialist in knowing every plant's healing property, she serves her community by helping the elders and does not charge them for remedies she prepares. This job helped her grow since she attended talks and conferences she was invited to. She had the opportunity to travel to Ecuador and the people she met there where medical therapists who enhanced her understanding. In turn, she was able to share with the medical specialists the healing discoveries she maD. while treating her patients. Not only was she able to buy the land she owns and lives on, with this job she was also able to build it, acquire artifacts, and pay for her children's education. Many of her patients are professionals (lawyers, politicians, nurses, and doctors) and locals who are grateful for Cecilia being able to cure many of their diseases such as cancer, tumors, cysts, and myomas; but only when a surgical intervention is not necessary. If they do need surgery she tells her patients they should have it since she verifies it through x-rays and ultra sound scanning. She thanks God for having guided her to this path of helping people with much love through her knowledge. Her goal is to travel with medics in the United States so they can learn about and spread this form of healing.

The loan she requests will be used to buy more syrups, herbs, and other natural healing medications.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Garza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more syrups, herbs, and other natural healing medications.

loans.name: Konooweka Zibba  Women's Group-Lugazi

texts.en:
In business, one has to take both the rough and the smooth along the way as he or she operates. That is the chequered nature of doing business. To sail through these waters safe and sound, one has to draw up blue print contingency plans on how to succeed without letting these affect the business. 

At least over the last 5 years that is exactly what 38 year old N. Harriet, who belongs to Konooweka ziba Group, Lugazi has done. She has taken time by the forelock in making decisions that have impacted positively on her clothes sales business in Ziba-Lugazi. Her business has been gaining ground, albeit the main problem has manifested itself in the lack of enough capital to purchase more bales of clothes to resell and henceforth make more profit. Harriet is a strong willed woman with a fun loving disposition. She is a happily married mother of 5 kids who all attend good schools in and around Ziba. To take root in this business she was helped by a close friend who gave her not only financial support but also confidence building advice on how to run a business. Harriet had no previous business experience. In a week she says she makes profits that add up to 150,000 shillings, and with this loan she is looking at buying more bales of clothes for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Yolanda Maria

texts.es:
Yolanda María S. S. es una mujer de 31 años  muy fuerte y trabajadora, propietaria de un taller de carpintería que nació hace 8 años y  que antes manejara su esposo, pero con su  fallecimiento hace 4,  se viò obligada a sobreponerse y dirigirlo, para continuar manteniendo la obligación de sus dos pequeños hijos de 6 y 10 años. Yolanda en su taller fabrica  multimuebles y closets, que vende en Barranquilla y en  Santa Marta,una  ciudad costera llamada la Perla del Caribe, por sus hermosos playas y paisajes naturales conservados, su espectacular sierra nevada y su protegido parque Tayrona conocido por su amplia gama de vegetación primaria.
Para Yolanda este es su primer credikiva, con el cual va a comprar materias primas como madera, pegantes, clavos, tornillos y accesorios, pues quiere posicionarse en su producto  estrella,  el closets,  aprovechando que éste mercado está creciendo por el auge que en la actualidad tiene el sector de la construcción. Su desafío mayor es mantener liquidez y por eso está recurriendo a los créditos de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, para solucionar este inconveniente productivo y avanzar en el crecimiento de su microempresa, asì más adelante cumplirà su sueño: "que sus hijos, tengan la mejor educación y puedan ser personas exitosas y destacadas en la profesión que escojan".
texts.en:
Yolanda María S. S., 31, is strong and hard working.  She owns a carpentry shop that was born 8 years ago that her husband used to run.  However, with his death four years ago, she was forced to overcome and start to run it herself in order to continue to support her two young, 6 and 10 year old, children.

Yolanda makes multi-use furniture and armoires that she sells in Barranquilla and Santa Marta, a coastal city known as the Pearl of the Caribbean, thanks to its beautiful beaches and conserved natural scenery, its spectacular Sierra Nevada and its protected Tayrona park with its wide range of native flora.

This is Yolanda’s first Kiva loan that she will use to buy raw materials like: wood, adhesives, nails, screws and accessories because she wants to better position herself with her star item, the armoire, now that home construction is booming.

Maintaining cash flow is her greatest challenge and this is why she has been counting on loans from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo to solve this snag in production and continue growing as a small business.  This way she hopes in the future to have her dream come true:  “that her children have the best education and become successful people who stand out in whatever profession they choose.”

loans.use: To buy raw materials like: wood, adhesives, nails, screws and accessories in greater amounts.

loans.name: Aracely Del Carmen

texts.es:
Aracely es una señora D. 44 años D. edad, resiD. en San Francisco Gotera y se dedica a la venta D. pescado y mariscos secos y frescos, este negocio lo tiene ubicado en la avenida D. comercio en San Francisco Gotera, está casada y vive con su esposo y sus tres hijos  Mario Francisco D. 22 años, Douglas Armando D. 17 y Carlos Daniel D. 14 años D. edad.
Este negocio lo inicio por su hermana aunque hoy trabaja sola con su familia, el proceso D. la obtención del pescado inicia desD. la madrugada cuando compra el pescado en San Miguel, y a las 8:00am ya esta lista la venta en Gotera para iniciar a comercializarla, ya tiene más D. 20 años D. estar en esta actividad por lo que por muchos años este ha sido su única fuente D. ingreso para crecer y educar a sus hijos.
En esta ocasión ella solicita un préstamo para impulsar aun más su comercio D. mariscos y al mismo tiempo como se acerca la fecha D. los difuntos y muchas personas compran coronas D. flores, quiere aprovechar para hacer flores y vender en esta temporada, invirtiendo el préstamo en un 50 y 50 por ciento. Esta inversión ayudara a que pueda generara mejores ingresos para cubrir los gastos en el hogar, su único riesgo con los mariscos es que tiene que venderlos rápido porque se daña cuando ya tiene varios días.
Su objetivo es obtener ganancias del negocio para educar a sus hijos y puedan ser unos profesionales, también cancelar oportunamente este préstamo y seguir trabajando para algún día contar con los fondos para construir su propia vivienda.
texts.en:
Aracely is a 44 year old woman who lives in San Francisco Gotera. She sells fish and seafood, both fresh and dried. She has her stand on a street named Avenida D. Comercio in San Francisco Gotera. She is married and she lives together with her husband and their three children: Mario Francisco, 22 years old; Douglas Armando, 17 years old; and, Carlos Daniel, 14 years old. 

She started out with her sister as a business partner but now she works only with her family.  She purchases the fresh fish in the very early morning hours in San Miguel and by 8am she is ready to start selling in Gotera. She has more than 20 years' experience in the business and it has been her only source of income used to support and educate her children. 

She requests a loan to revitalize her seafood business and now especially that the day of the dead approaches and many people buy flowers, she wants to take advantage of the season and sell in this time. She plans to invest 50% of the funds on each one of her two businesses. This investment will help her generate more earnings to be used to supplement the family economy. The only risk has to sell the fresh seafood quickly to avoid losing freshness over several days. 

Her goal is to garner enough profit to send her kids to school, to help them have a career. She will also use her profits to repay this loan, and to save money enough to build her own home one day.

loans.use: To purchase seafood and flowers.

loans.name: Hamidou Ousmane

texts.fr:
Né le 19 Octobre 1988 à Zégoua (frontière Mali-Côte d’Ivoire), Monsieur Hamidou Ousmane D. est un célibataire sans enfant résidant chez son cousin à Sanoubougou II, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Hamidou Ousmane D. n’ayant pas eu la chance de progresser dans les études, il s’est très vite initié à cette activité d’achat et vente des téléphones portables et leurs accessoires (façades, batteries, chargeurs, écouteurs, etc.) il y a maintenant dix ans. Son activité est menée dans sa propre boutique à la gare routière de Sikasso avec une clientèle composée essentiellement des voyageurs et surtout des transporteurs. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il bénéficié d’un premier prêt qui fut correctement remboursé. Ainsi, il sollicite un deuxième prêt lui permettant d’acheter à Bamako 24 téléphones portables de marques différentes, 3 cartons de façades, 25 chargeurs, 20 paquets de carte mémoire, 5 cartons de batterie, 5 douzaines d’écouteurs, une dizaine de montres différentes, des ceintures, etc. 
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 230 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born on October 19, 1988 in Zégoua (on the border of Mali and Côte d’Ivoire), Mr. Hamidou Ousmane D. is a single man without children, who lives with his cousin in Sanoubougou II, one of the popular neighborhoods in the city of Sikasso (third administrative region in the Republic of Mali).  Hamidou Ousmane D. never had the chance to progress in his studies, so he quickly joined the business of selling cellular phones and their accessories (cases, batteries, chargers, head-sets, etc.), and has been doing so for ten years.  His business is run from his own small shop at the bus station in Sikasso with a clientele made up mostly of travelers and especially transporters of goods.  He is sought out by his clients for the high quality of his products.

With the goal of better serving his growing clientele, he decided to work with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom he profited from an initial loan which was entirely paid back.  As such, he is seeking a second loan which will allow him to purchase 24 cell phones of various brands, three boxes of cases/face plates, 25 chargers, 20 bundles of memory cards, five boxes of batteries, five dozen head-sets, and a dozen different holsters, belts, etc. from Bamako.

With this loan, he looks to earn monthly profits of 230,000 FCFA which will be used primarily for family expenses, to pay the interest on his loan, and to invest the remainder in his business.

loans.use: To buy cellular phone accessories

loans.name: Kalbubu's Group

texts.en:
Kalbubu I. is the leader of this group. She is 48 and divorced. She has two daughters and a son. Her son works as a teacher and her daughters are married and live separately with their own families. Five years ago, with the initial investment of 1000 soms, Kalbubu started to take orders to sew Kyrgyz national blankets and pillows. In this way she makes 4000 soms per month. She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase fabrics and materials for sewing.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase fabric and materials.

loans.name: Marina Uson Group

texts.en:
Marina U. is from the village of Cebu San Isidro. She is 54 years old. Marina is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Marina U.. 

Marina is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Marina owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes  from selling charcoal, fish sauce, salt and other basic commodities.. Marina has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities. 

In 2009, Marina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marina is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be Marina's 4th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Juna

texts.en:
Juna P. is from the village of Maquilao in Tangub City. She is 40 years old. Juna is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Juna raises and sells fish. Juna has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 1500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Juna joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from GDMPC. Juna is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Juna from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Silverio

texts.es:
Silverio vive con su esposa y sus dos hijos en el distrito de Wanchaq. El distrito de Wanchaq se encuentra ubicado en la provincia del Cusco del departamento del Cusco, llamada el distrito de las flores y localizándose a 5 minutos de la plaza de armas de la capital arqueológica de América del Sur (Cusco). Cusco es una ciudad encantadora que se remonta a los tiempos de los Incas, la ciudad del Cusco está construida en la base de la antigua ciudadela Inca. 

Silverio trabaja como administrador de una empresa privada. Con su próximo préstamo, Silverio que espera recibir S/.500 nuevos soles. Este dinero es para uso personal y no especifica con detalle para que exactamente. 

Silverio pertenece al banco comunal “Nueva Esperanza” de la Asociación Arariwa. El banco comunal esta en el segundo año de funcionamiento y está bien administrado por la junta directiva.
texts.en:
Silverio lives with his wife and two children in Wanchaq district.  Wanchaq district is located in Cusco province, in Cusco department.  It is called 'The Flower District' and is located 5 minutes from the Plaza de Armas in the archaeological capital of South America (Cusco).  Cusco is a delightful city that dates back to Incan times.  The city of Cusco is built on the site of the ancient Incan citadel.

Silverio works as an administrator in a private company.  He hopes to receive a loan for 500 Peruvian soles.  This money is for personal use and he does not specify in detail what exactly it is for.

Silverio belongs to Asociación Arariwa's "Nueva Esperanza" (New Hope) community bank which is in its second year and is well run by its board of directors.

loans.use: For personal use

loans.name: Koch

texts.en: Koch C. is a 43-year-old married woman from Kompong Chhnang Province. To earn a living, Koch C. sells porridge in front of her house to her neighbors and to other villagers who need to have breakfast. Usually, Koch C. generates around 1.25 USD of profit per day to meet the needs of her family. She has other financial sources from her husband. He works as a building worker, earning an income of approximately 1.25 USD per day. They have five children. Four children are single, and the other one is married and lives away from home. Koch C. is taking out a loan to purchase a piece of farmland in a good location for farming, on which she will grow different kinds of crops. Note: Koch C. and her young child are pictured in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase a piece of farmland in a good location for farming

loans.name: Farkhad

texts.en:
Farkhad A. is from Sabirabad. He is 49 years old, married, and is blessed with two sons. The high aim for Farkhad is to provide a better life for this family and to give a good education to his children. His wife helps him in this goal. They are a very diligent family. 

To improve their living, Farkhad has been engaged in a trading business for over 10 years. After the first loan taken out from AqroInvest and Kiva, the income of his family increased up to 500 AZN per month.   Farkhad was able to open a new grocery store.  He is very thankful for the support rendered to him.

With the help of this second loan in the amount of 1500 AZN, Farkhad stocked the shelves of his store with more goods. After he repays this loan, he plans to apply for more loans to grow his business and to enlarge his new store.

loans.use: To buy inventory for grocery store

loans.name: Robelyn

texts.en:
Mrs. Robelyn Y. is from the village of P3 Tabid, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old, married, and blessed with two school-aged children. To make a living, she is presently engaged in a recycling business. She’s been engaged in this kind of business activity for five years already. She’s earning an average of not less than $75 a month from this kind of scrap recycling activity. 

In March of 2007, Robelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is an active member of Paglaum MPC under the PDP-LP, a micro-finance program that reaches out to rural communities, and she has successfully repaid a loan of 5,000 PHP. 

Robelyn is now requesting 7,000 PHP which will be her 6th loan and will be used for starting a hog fattening business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family, especially in meeting their basic needs, savings for future use, loan repayments, her children’s education and possible business expansions.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders

loans.use: for starting a hog fattening business

loans.name: Bekhbayar

texts.en: Bekhbayar is 37 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They all live together in a ger (a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent) on his brother-in-law’s plot of land. His two eldest children attend a local secondary school and the youngest daughter is just one year old and stays at home with his wife. Bekhbayar has been operating a taxi business in the city for the last one and a half years. He is an energetic and enthusiastic person who says, “I would like to be financially able to provide a good education and cover other expenses for my children.” The loan that he is asking for is to increase his working capital to buy some spare parts for his car.

loans.use: To increase his working capital

loans.name: Lorena Elizabeth

texts.es:
Lorena de 32 años, es una mujer trabajadora que tiene una pequeña papelería. Para poder tener su papelería ella tuvo que esforzarse mucho y con ayuda de su padrastro con un capital que le prestó puedo surtir su negocio. 

En la actualidad vende papelería como cuadernos, hojas, plumas, carpetas etc. Trabaja sola desde muy temprano atendiendo a los clientes con una buena predisposición. Tiene muchas aspiraciones con su negocio por eso quiere seguir trabajando. Quiere el préstamo para comprar cuadernos, hojas, carpetas, plumas etc.
texts.en:
Lorena, 32 years old, is a hardworking woman who owns a small stationary store.  In order to get her store she had to work very hard, and she had help from her step-father in the form of capital that he loaned her so that she could stock the store.  

Currently she sells stationary items like notebooks, loose-leaf paper, pens, folders, etc.  Beginning very early in the morning she works alone, attending to the customers with a good disposition.  She has many aspirations for her business, and for this reason wants to keep working.  She wants the loan to buy notebooks, paper, folders, pens, etc.

loans.use: to buy notebooks, loose-leaf paper, and pens

loans.name: Khemra's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Khemra has been selected as group leader of a group of four members who are taking out this loan in the hope that it will improve their families' standards of living.

Mr. Khemra was born in 1981. He is a pig breeder and a Khmer cheese seller in local market where he can earn some profit to support his family. Since his business is getting on well, he wants to expand. So to this end Mr. Khemra is seeking a loan to buy more Khmer cheese for resale. His wife, Mrs. Chenda, is a farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land where she can grow rice to help support her family.

This couple supports two children, one of whom is a student, while the youngest one is 2 years old.

loans.use: to buy more Khmer cheese for resale

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe is a married woman living in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato with her family. She has been raising pigs for 30 years. She sells the pigs at the market. Fe's husband is a farmer and she helps him maintain their rice farm.

Fe plans to use her loan to purchase pig feed, rice seeds and fertilizers. Fe does her best to improve their businesses.

loans.use: to purchase pig feed, rice seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Ivtasim

texts.en:
Ivtasim lives in Shfaram where she opened her pita baking business last year. For years she has worked for the Municipality as a cleaner in area schools but sought an avenue to create much needed additional income. She now bakes hand-made pita with "zaatar" (local thyme) and small pizzas. Over the last year she has gained a local clientele and has begun selling "pitot" and pizzas to area schools and kindergartens.

Ivtasim needed this loan to purchase a kneading machine, an additional baking oven, wood and supplies.

Ivtasim wants to continue in her business's expansion. With the kneading machine she is able to produce larger quantity. She hopes to expand her private client base and sell to additional schools and child care settings which have a high demand for steady supply.

loans.use: to buy a kneading machine, additional baking oven, wood and supplies.
